description:
First attested 1400–50. From Middle English abbreviacioun, from Middle French abreviation, from Ecclesiastical Latin abbreviātiō, from Latin ad + breviō (“shorten”), from brevis (“short”).
Morphologically abbreviate +‎ -ion

nouns.description: abbreviation (countable and uncountable, plural abbreviations), used with for or of

entries.meaning: The result of shortening or reducing; abridgment. [First attested around 1350 to 1470.]

(linguistics) A shortened or contracted form of a word or phrase, used to represent the whole, utilizing omission of letters, and sometimes substitution of letters, or duplication of initial letters to signify plurality, including signs such as +, =, @. [Late 16th century.]
examples: Hants is an abbreviation of Hampshire.

entries.meaning: (music) A notation used in music score to denote a direction, as pp or mf.
(music) One or more dashes through the stem of a note, dividing it respectively into quavers, semiquavers, demisemiquavers, or hemidemisemiquavers.
Any convenient short form used as a substitution for an understood or inferred whole.
examples: The phrase "civil rights" is an abbreviation for a whole complex of relationships.

entries.meaning: (biology) Loss during evolution of the final stages of the ancestral ontogenetic pattern.
(mathematics) Reduction to lower terms, as a fraction.
